hedline.hl1: Trial Judge Comments on Microsoft Ruling

abstract.p: Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson says he knows his rulings in Microsoft Corp antitrust case are controversial, but he has no regrets, antitrust conference sponsored by George Mason University; says he knows virtually everything in rulings may be vulnerable on appeal; says 'Microsoft intransigence' left him no choice (S)

block.p: Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson says he knows his rulings in the Microsoft antitrust case are controversial, but he has no regrets, even though, as he put it today, ''virtually everything I did may be vulnerable on appeal.''
Speaking to an antitrust conference sponsored by George Mason University, Judge Jackson said a breakup of the company, which he ordered in June, ''was never my remedy of choice.''

Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson says he knows his rulings in the Microsoft antitrust case are controversial, but he has no regrets, even though, as he put it today, ''virtually everything I did may be vulnerable on appeal.''
Speaking to an antitrust conference sponsored by George Mason University, Judge Jackson said a breakup of the company, which he ordered in June, ''was never my remedy of choice.''
He added, however, that ''Microsoft intransigence'' left him no choice.

Judge Jackson has made many of these remarks before. In fact, Microsoft recently tried to use one of his comments against him. In a appellate court brief, the company quoted him as saying his rulings were vulnerable on appeal in an effort to bolster its case.
Last spring, Judge Jackson found Microsoft in wide violation of state and federal antitrust laws and ordered the company broken up. Those rulings are now on appeal.

In earlier interviews, Judge Jackson acknowledged that he followed a long learning curve as he worked to understand the technological issues underlying the case. Trying to short-circuit that, the appellate court invited a technology expert to hold a computer-technology seminar for the judges next month, one that would not touch upon the issues in the trial.

But both Microsoft and the government raised questions about that idea, and on Thursday the court, in a one-paragraph statement, said it would not proceed with the review session ''upon consideration of the parties' responses'' to the plan.
